properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Audio Files and iToonsical go to Capital Fringe! at Source Theater
properties.description:
From cartoon musical inspired improv to hilarity through the radio age to the iPod age WIT will keep you laughing and entertained at this year’s Capital Fringe Festival
Join Audio Files and iToonsical at Source Theater on Saturday and Sunday 7.8-7.23 at 8PM and 10PM and Sunday 7.10-7.24 at 2PM, 8PM and 10PM for giggles, chuckles, snickers and straight up rolling-on-the-floor laughter.
iToonsical takes on Disney’s most prized possession with completely improvised scenes, lyrics and music all inspired by audience suggestion. Then comes a two-in-one deal with Audio Files, a combination of WIT’s show’s The Source and WIRT. First, WIRT uses only their voices to adventure back to the time of detective radio shows. Then The Source shifts to modern times, hijacking an audience member’s iPod to create a score to their improvised scene.
Tickets for Audio Files, iToonsical and the many other Fringe shows will go on sale June 20th. For more information about Capital Fringe, check out their website at capitalfringe.org or head over to Fort Fringe & the Baldacchino Gypsy Tent Bar at 607 New York Ave. NW.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: John Witherspoon from "The Boondocks," "House Party" and the "Friday" trilogy at DC Improv Comedy Club
properties.description:
You probably remember John Witherspoon as Ice Cube's outrageously funny, dog-catching father in the "Friday" movie trilogy, where the two were the only cast members to appear in all three movies, including "Next Friday" & "Friday After Next." You may also remember him as Pops on the long-running sitcom "The Wayans Brothers," or as Spoon on The Tracy Morgan Show on NBC. You might have also heard him as the voice of Robert "Granddad" Freeman on the hit animated series "The Boondocks." No matter how familiar you are with John, once you see him perform live you completely understand why he's has earned his reputation as one of the funniest dads in America.
John's scene-stealing roles in "Boomerang," "Little Nicky," "House Party," "Vampire in Brooklyn," and "I'm Gonna Git You Sucka," has established him as a Hollywood mainstay. Witherspoon's resume spans over four decades and his performances in blockbuster movies, hit-television shows, and top-rated music videos have left an impression on legions of fans who instantly recognize his signature catchphrases like "Bang!Bang!Bang!Bang!" "You gotta co-ordinate!" and "Don't nobody go in the bathroom..."
According to the Orange County Register, John's expressive talent puts him in a class of his own. "Witherspoon is one of those performers who doesn't need a funny line to be funny. Just standing there in a truculent posture with a suspicious look, he is funny and enlivens every scene he's in." The Detroit-bred comic has proven that he is a Hollywood mainstay and continues to land coveted spots in some of America's favorite movies and television shows. Witherspoon continues to tour around the country with his wildly popular stand-up show, plus he's recently launched The John Witherspoon Collection, a complete line of humorous greeting cards called Spoon Cards.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Bela Fleck and the Flecktones With Abigail Washburn at Pier Six Concert Pavilion
Jul  7, 2011: Puppet Show at Watkins Regional Park
properties.description: Enjoy a seasonal-themed puppet show, and meet several live animals.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Guided Tours of the Anderson House Museum at Anderson House Museum
properties.description: This museum houses artifacts from the Revolutionary War, portraits by early American artists, 18th-century paintings, 17th-century tapestries, decorative arts of Europe and Asia and displays of books, medals, swords, silver, glass, china and more.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Letters and Diaries of the Civil War at Fredericksburg Area Museum and Cultural Center
properties.description: This is the second in a series of shows created as part of the statewide commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Civil War. The exhibit features over thirty original letters and diaries, written by soldiers and civilians, about the conflict that engulfed this region from 1861-1865. Included are documents from the Museum's own collection as well as pieces on loan from the National Park Service, the Library of Virginia, the Virginia Historical Society, the Museum of the Confederacy and private collectors.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Faces at the Races: the Equine Culture of Virginia at Fredericksburg Area Museum and Cultural Center
properties.description: Through classical black and white portraiture, the exhibit documents the people and institutions that truly represent Horse Culture in Virginia. In the 1700s Virginia emerged as the pre-eminent horse breeding area in America. Today, horses remain a major interest in the Commonwealth from Middleburg to Bristol. The Commonwealth is home to more than 225,000 horses, while the equine industry contributes at least a billion dollars to the economy each year. Images in this exhibition represent owners, riders, trainers, audience members, and others from events such as the Middleburg Spring Horse Show, The Montpellier Point-to-Point, and The Upperville Colt and Horse Show, which is the oldest horse show in the United States. Faces at the Races will be on exhibit in our Mansard Gallery.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Weekday Boat Rides at Bladensburg Waterfront Park
properties.description: Join a park naturalist on our 40-seat pontoon boat for an environmental or historical tour of the scenic Anacostia River.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Calder's Portraits: A New Language at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: Best known for his abstract mobiles and stabiles, Alexander Calder (1898-1976) was also a prolific portraitist. This unprecedented exhibition will feature Calder's work alongside contemporary documents - photographs, drawings, and especially caricatures by such artist-illustrators as Paolo Garretto, Miguel Covarrubias, and Paul Colin - and will pose questions regarding the line between fine-art portraiture and caricature.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: 150th Commemoration of the Civil War: the Death of Ellsworth at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition recounts the death of Colonel Elmer E. Ellsworth in Alexandria, VA. Ellsworth, a friend of President Abraham Lincoln, was the first Union officer to be killed in the four-year-long struggle. Throughout the Civil War his name, face and heroism was recalled in stationery, sheet music and memorial lithographs. Francis E. Brownell, the soldier who mortally avenged Ellsworth's assailant, bequeathed several artifacts to the Smithsonian Institution, including the weapons used in the incident and Brownell's Congressional Medal of Honor. The exhibition will bring together a select grouping of once-prized mementoes, including portraits of Ellsworth and Lincoln, as well as Alonzo Chappel's historic painting, 'The Death of Ellsworth.'

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Capital Portraits: Treasures From Washington Private Collections at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition presents portraits that reside in private Washington, D.C. collections. Many of the works have never been on public display. Works included are by major artists such as John Singleton Copley, Mary Cassatt, Andy Warhol and Kehinde Wiley. Featuring aesthetically superior images from 1750 to the present, this exhibition demonstrates how portraiture is ingrained in the private sphere of people's lives and offers an insiders peek to the public.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Glimpse of the Past: A Neighborhood Evolves at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: 'Glimpse of the Past' is a photographic exploration of the neighborhood surrounding the Patent Office Building, one of the oldest federal buildings in Washington, D.C. and now home to the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum. On display are images from the 1850s to the present, which showcase the rise, decline and revival of the area. An interactive in the exhibition will also feature snapshots of the area during the 1960s and 1970s made by Washingtonian Chris Earnshaw.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Close to Home: Photographers and Their Families at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: 'Close to Home' presents photographs made during the past three decades by both established and emerging artists. On display are 32 color and black-and-white photographs from the Smithsonian American Art Museum's permanent collection by nine contemporary photographers: Tina Barney, Virginia Beahan, Christopher Dawson, Muriel Hasbun, Martina Lopez, Elaine O'Neil, Larry Sultan, Margaret Strickland, and Carrie Will. The exhibition includes many new acquisitions, which will be on view at the museum for the first time. Toby Jurovics, formerly the museum's curator of photography, selected the photographs in the installation.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: To Make A World: George Ault and 1940s America at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: This exhibition centers on five paintings Ault made between 1943 and 1948 depicting the crossroads of Russell's Corners in Woodstock, N.Y. The additional 22 artists represented in this exhibition include some as celebrated as Edward Hopper and Andrew Wyeth, while others are scarcely known to today's art audiences. Taken together, their artworks reveal an aesthetic vein running through 1940s American art that previously has not been identified. From their remote corners of the country, these artists conveyed a still quietude that seems filled with potentialities.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Smithsonian Folklife Festival at The National Mall
properties.description: The Festival generally includes daily and evening programs of music, song, dance, celebratory performance, crafts and cooking demonstrations, storytelling, illustrations of workers' culture, and narrative sessions for discussing cultural issues. This year's Festival features programs on Colombia, Peace Corps and Rhythm and Blues.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: From Impressionism to Modernism: the Chester Dale Collection at National Gallery of Art - East Building
properties.description: This exhibit will bring together 84 of the finest French and American paintings that Chester Dale and his wife Maud, an artist and critic, assembled from the 1920s through the 1950s.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Seasons: Chinese Flowers at Freer Gallery of Art
properties.description: This exhibition features paintings of Chinese flowers native to each season.
